awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Ian Jauslin is "Spontaneous ordering in many-body particle systems fluid flows." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University and the sponsoring scientist is Elliott Lieb.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research carried out in this project concerns the mathematical
understanding of four physical processes: the formation of crystals and liquid
crystals, electron emission from metals, and Bose-Einstein condensation.

Much of matter is commonly described as being in one of three distinct phases:
gas, liquid, or solid. However, our mathematical understanding of this process
is limited. A paradigmatic toy model that was introduced to understand these
transitions is the hard sphere model, in which particles are represented as
spheres, with the constraint that they may not overlap. It has been conjectured
that, at low densities, the spheres should form a gas phase, and at high
densities, a solid, crystalline phase. This is a very difficult problem, and
the research in this project has taken some steps in the direction of a
solution, by considering a family of simpler models, in which the particles are
constrained to a discrete set of positions. The PI and collaborators have
identified a class of such models for which they proved that, at low density,
the system is in a gaseous phase, and, at high densities, it transitions to a
crystal.

Liquid crystals are materials that share some properties of liquids (they flow
and form drops), as well as some properties of crystals (which are mostly seen
in their optical properties). They have been used in flat screen display
technology since the 1970's. Liquid crystals typically occur in systems of
anisotropic molecules, that are roughly shaped like rigid rods. The liquid
crystal phase is one in which the positions of the molecules are disordered,
but their orientation is ordered (which gives them non-trivial optical
properties). From a mathematical perspective, it is still an open problem to
show that such a phase exists in a realistic molecular model of matter. In
1979, Heilmann and Lieb conjectured that, in a simplified model in which
molecules are interacting dimers on a lattice, the system should form a liquid
crystal phase. The PI and collaborators have proved this conjecture.
Furthermore, the PI and collaborators have proved the existence of a liquid
crystal phase in a system of hard plates in three dimensions with discrete
orientations, which is the first result of its kind in three dimensions.

The work on crystallization and liquid crystals was started before, and
completed during the award period.

Electron emission is a process by which electrons are extracted from a
substrate. One procedure to accomplish this is to shine an intense laser pulse
on a metal. The basic idea of the process is that electrons in a metal are
bound to the atoms in the metal, but the laser can give them enough energy to
break these bonds and escape. This process is used in scientific experiments to
produce high-energy electronic beams. The equation that is commonly used to
study such experiments is, however, rather difficult to study mathematically.
In this project, the PI and collaborators have designed a stable numerical
algorithm to compute the solutions of this equation. In addition, they have
laid the groundwork for a rigorous analysis of the long-time behavior of the
equation. This analysis has extended beyond the end of this award, and will
appear in a future publication.

Quantum particles can be of one of two types: Bosons or Fermions, the
difference being that two Fermions cannot be in the same state at the same
time, whereas Bosons can, and do: at low temperatures, it has been predicted
that Bosons form a Bose-Einstein condensate, in which most particles are in the
same state. This is an important fact, as it enables large-scale collective
behavior, and has been posited to be an underlying mechanism for superfluidity
(flow without friction) and superconductivity (electrical currents without
resistance). However, the existence of Bose-Einstein condensates has only been
proved in the cases in which Bosons do not interact, or when the density of
Bosons is infinitely low. The PI and collaborators have introduced a new
approach to systems of Bosons, called the Simplified approach, in which
Bose-Einstein condensation can be proved to occur. Now, the simplified approach
has not been proved to exactly model a gas of Bosons, but it may be possible to
show that, at low densities, it is exact, and would thus be a step towards a
proof of Bose-Einstein condensation. But what is more, the PI and collaborators
have found that the Simplified Approach reproduces some of the known and
conjectured behavior of Bosons at all densities, not just small ones, thus
providing a new tool to study systems of Bosons beyond the density regimes in
which they have traditionally been studied.

* Intellectual merit:
These results have advanced the state of knowledge in several directions, and
introduced new approaches to attempt to solve important open problems in
mathematical physics.

* Broader impact:
The research is related to physical systems that have technological
applications. Furthermore, all findings have been made available for free on
the arXiv and the PI's website, as well as the software written, so that anyone
interested in using them can do so freely.
